column2: CHAPTER II--A DOUBLE QUARTETTE
column3: CHAPTER two-A DOUBLE QUARTETTE

column2: These young men were insignificant; every one has seen such faces; four specimens of humanity taken at random; neither good nor bad, neither wise nor ignorant, neither geniuses nor fools; handsome, with that charming April which is called twenty years.
column3: These young men were insignificant; every one has seen such faces; four specimens of humanity taken at random; neither good nor bad, neither wise nor ignorant, neither geniuses nor fools; handsome, with that charming April which is called twenty years.

column2: They were four Oscars; for, at that epoch, Arthurs did not yet exist.
column3: They were four Oscars; for, at that epoch, Arthurs did not yet exist.

column2: Burn for him the perfumes of Araby! exclaimed romance.
column3: Burn for him the perfumes of Araby! exclaimed romance.

column2: Oscar advances.
column3: Oscar advances.

column2: Oscar, I shall behold him! People had just emerged from Ossian; elegance was Scandinavian and Caledonian; the pure English style was only to prevail later, and the first of the Arthurs, Wellington, had but just won the battle of Waterloo.
column3: Oscar, I shall behold him! People had just emerged from Ossian; elegance was Scandinavian and Caledonian; the pure English style was only to prevail later, and the first of the Arthurs, Wellington, had but just won the battle of Waterloo.

column2: Favourite, Dahlia, Zephine, and Fantine were four ravishing young women, perfumed and radiant, still a little like working-women, and not yet entirely divorced from their needles; somewhat disturbed by intrigues, but still retaining on their faces something of the serenity of toil, and in their souls that flower of honesty which survives the first fall in woman.
column3: Favourite, Dahlia, Zephine, and Fantine were four ravishing young women, perfumed and radiant, still a little like working women, and not yet entirely divorced from their needles; somewhat disturbed by intrigues, but still retaining on their faces something of the serenity of toil, and in their souls that flower of honesty which survives the first fall in woman.

column2: Not to conceal anything, the three first were more experienced, more heedless, and more emancipated into the tumult of life than Fantine the Blonde, who was still in her first illusions.
column3: Not to conceal anything, the three first were more experienced, more heedless, and more emancipated into the tumult of life than Fantine the Blonde, who was still in her first illusions.

column2: Poverty and coquetry are two fatal counsellors; one scolds and the other flatters, and the beautiful daughters of the people have both of them whispering in their ear, each on its own side.
column3: Poverty and coquetry are two fatal counsellors; one scolds and the other flatters, and the beautiful daughters of the people have both of them whispering in their ear, each on its own side.

column2: These badly guarded souls listen.
column3: These badly guarded souls listen.

column2: Hence the falls which they accomplish, and the stones which are thrown at them.
column3: Hence the falls which they accomplish, and the stones which are thrown at them.

column2: They are overwhelmed with splendor of all that is immaculate and inaccessible.
column3: They are overwhelmed with splendor of all that is immaculate and inaccessible.

column2: Her father was an old unmarried professor of mathematics, a brutal man and a braggart, who went out to give lessons in spite of his age.
column3: Her father was an old unmarried professor of mathematics, a brutal man and a braggart, who went out to give lessons in spite of his age.

column2: This professor, when he was a young man, had one day seen a chambermaid's gown catch on a fender; he had fallen in love in consequence of this accident.
column3: This professor, when he was a young man, had one day seen a chambermaid's gown catch on a fender; he had fallen in love in consequence of this accident.

column2: The result had been Favourite.
column3: The result had been Favourite.

column2: She met her father from time to time, and he bowed to her.
column3: She met her father from time to time, and he bowed to her.

column2: One morning an old woman with the air of a devotee, had entered her apartments, and had said to her, "You do not know me, Mamemoiselle?" "No."
column3: One morning an old woman with the air of a devotee, had entered her apartments, and had said to her, "You do not know me, Mamemoiselle?" "no"

column2: I am your mother. Then the old woman opened the sideboard, and ate and drank, had a mattress which she owned brought in, and installed herself.
column3: I am your mother. Then the old woman opened the sideboard, and ate and drank, had a mattress which she owned brought in, and installed herself.

column2: This cross and pious old mother never spoke to Favourite, remained hours without uttering a word, breakfasted, dined, and supped for four, and went down to the porter's quarters for company, where she spoke ill of her daughter.
column3: This cross and pious old mother never spoke to Favourite, remained hours without uttering a word, breakfasted, dined, and supped for four, and went down to the porter's quarters for company, where she spoke ill of her daughter.

column2: How could she make such nails work?
column3: How could she make such nails work?

column2: She who wishes to remain virtuous must not have pity on her hands. As for Zephine, she had conquered Fameuil by her roguish and caressing little way of saying "Yes, sir."
column3: She who wishes to remain virtuous must not have pity on her hands. As for Zephine, she had conquered Fameuil by her roguish and caressing little way of saying "Yes, sir."

column2: The young men were comrades; the young girls were friends.
column3: The young men were comrades; the young girls were friends.

column2: Such loves are always accompanied by such friendships.
column3: Such loves are always accompanied by such friendships.

column2: Goodness and philosophy are two distinct things; the proof of this is that, after making all due allowances for these little irregular households, Favourite, Zephine, and Dahlia were philosophical young women, while Fantine was a good girl.
column3: Goodness and philosophy are two distinct things; the proof of this is that, after making all due allowances for these little irregular households, Favourite, Zephine, and Dahlia were philosophical young women, while Fantine was a good girl.

column2: Solomon would reply that love forms a part of wisdom.
column3: Solomon would reply that love forms a part of wisdom.

column2: We will confine ourselves to saying that the love of Fantine was a first love, a sole love, a faithful love.
column3: We will confine ourselves to saying that the love of Fantine was a first love, a sole love, a faithful love.

column2: She alone, of all the four, was not called "thou" by a single one of them.
column3: She alone, of all the four, was not called "thou" by a single one of them.

column2: Though she had emerged from the most unfathomable depths of social shadow, she bore on her brow the sign of the anonymous and the unknown.
column3: Though she had emerged from the most unfathomable depths of social shadow, she bore on her brow the sign of the anonymous and the unknown.

column2: Who can say?
column3: Who can say?

column2: She had never known father or mother.
column3: She had never known father or mother.

column2: Why Fantine?
column3: Why Fantine?

column2: She had never borne any other name.
column3: She had never borne any other name.

column2: At the epoch of her birth the Directory still existed.
column3: At the epoch of her birth the Directory still existed.

column2: She had no family name; she had no family; no baptismal name; the Church no longer existed.
column3: She had no family name; she had no family; no baptismal name; the Church no longer existed.

column2: She was called little Fantine.
column3: She was called little Fantine.

column2: No one knew more than that.
column3: No one knew more than that.

column2: This human creature had entered life in just this way.
column3: This human creature had entered life in just this way.

column2: At the age of ten, Fantine quitted the town and went to service with some farmers in the neighborhood.
column3: At the age of ten, Fantine quitted the town and went to service with some farmers in the neighborhood.

column2: At fifteen she came to Paris "to seek her fortune." Fantine was beautiful, and remained pure as long as she could.
column3: At fifteen she came to Paris "to seek her fortune." Fantine was beautiful, and remained pure as long as she could.

column2: She had gold and pearls for her dowry; but her gold was on her head, and her pearls were in her mouth.
column3: She had gold and pearls for her dowry; but her gold was on her head, and her pearls were in her mouth.

column2: She worked for her living; then, still for the sake of her living,--for the heart, also, has its hunger,--she loved.
column3: She worked for her living; then, still for the sake of her living,--for the heart, also, has its hunger,--she loved.

column2: An amour for him; passion for her.
column3: An amour for him; passion for her.

column2: The streets of the Latin quarter, filled with throngs of students and grisettes, saw the beginning of their dream.
column3: The streets of the Latin quarter, filled with throngs of students and grisettes, saw the beginning of their dream.

column2: In short, the eclogue took place.
column3: In short, the eclogue took place.

column2: It was he who possessed the wit.
column3: It was he who possessed the wit.

column2: Tholomyes was the antique old student; he was rich; he had an income of four thousand francs; four thousand francs! a splendid scandal on Mount Sainte-Genevieve.
column3: Tholomyes was the antique old student; he was rich; he had an income of four thousand francs; four thousand francs! a splendid scandal on Mount Sainte Genevieve.

column2: Tholomyes was a fast man of thirty, and badly preserved.
column3: Tholomyes was a fast man of thirty, and badly preserved.

column2: His digestion was mediocre, and he had been attacked by a watering in one eye.
column3: His digestion was mediocre, and he had been attacked by a watering in one eye.

column2: But in proportion as his youth disappeared, gayety was kindled; he replaced his teeth with buffooneries, his hair with mirth, his health with irony, his weeping eye laughed incessantly. He was dilapidated but still in flower.
column3: But in proportion as his youth disappeared, gayety was kindled; he replaced his teeth with buffooneries, his hair with mirth, his health with irony, his weeping eye laughed incessantly. He was dilapidated but still in flower.

column2: His youth, which was packing up for departure long before its time, beat a retreat in good order, bursting with laughter, and no one saw anything but fire.
column3: His youth, which was packing up for departure long before its time, beat a retreat in good order, bursting with laughter, and no one saw anything but fire.

column2: He had had a piece rejected at the Vaudeville.
column3: He had had a piece rejected at the Vaudeville.

column2: Being thus ironical and bald, he was the leader.
column3: Being thus ironical and bald, he was the leader.

column2: Iron is an English word.
column3: Iron is an English word.

column2: Is it possible that irony is derived from it?
column3: Is it possible that irony is derived from it?

column2: We have promised them solemnly that we would.
column3: We have promised them solemnly that we would.

column2: Thereupon, Tholomyes lowered his voice and articulated something so mirthful, that a vast and enthusiastic grin broke out upon the four mouths simultaneously, and Blachevelle exclaimed, "That is an idea."
column3: Thereupon, Tholomyes lowered his voice and articulated something so mirthful, that a vast and enthusiastic grin broke out upon the four mouths simultaneously, and Blachevelle exclaimed, "That is an idea."

column2: A smoky tap-room presented itself; they entered, and the remainder of their confidential colloquy was lost in shadow.
column3: A smoky tap room presented itself; they entered, and the remainder of their confidential colloquy was lost in shadow.

column2: The result of these shades was a dazzling pleasure party which took place on the following Sunday, the four young men inviting the four young girls.
column3: The result of these shades was a dazzling pleasure party which took place on the following Sunday, the four young men inviting the four young girls.
